Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> I honestly don't even know what it is. Not making any kind of value judgment there, but simply proclaiming my ignorance. On the other hand, I know how F'ed I would be if my VPS/Wallet/Keys and stakes were compromised:(

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> I realize it's not top of your list-- not complaining-- just curious if in your opinion it is in the realm of possibility

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Patrick ManBearPig that's an easier question to put some thought into. it is not obvious how that would work actually

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> staking is actually processing transactions like mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, it needs to validate an entire block of transactions and send them to the network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> which is what earns the stake reward. Komodo interest is really just interest. not actual staking

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so, it can happen just with the tx sitting there

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> I am sure it's not entirely the same with ERC20 tokens, but there are tokens out there which you can earn rewards while your stake is in a hardware wallet. TNT, Smartcash probably others

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <paia> but for example Smartcash requires smartnode linked to staking wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <paia> thats more expensive than running Agama wallet on your computer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> It seems like there should be some possible way of proving a stake beyond the coins being held in a hot unencrypted wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> certainly a chain can be designed to provide passive inflation and distribution of rewards to holders, but to do actual staking, which is rewarding people for their contribution to processing transactions, there has to be some way to validate and process a block. delegating holdings to someone else is potentially doable, but there are centralization issues with that as well, and the staking model we have now contributes in an important way to decentralization that will be even more important with PBaaS

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <paia> Verus is using just a different approach, that is more user friendly imho

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> proving a stake is the thing that lets you process the block

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the block still must be processed by someone

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> and generally, since we only have transactions and blocks as ways to make a record that others can validate, we need to use them for proof as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> Ok, so just looking at TNT for example, you hold 5k tnt in an ethereum wallet. Run a VPS which is available to process hashes. If your ethereum address does not hold the 5k tokens then you are not eligible for rewards

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> but you are running a node which processes transactions/audits etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that's more like a master node

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> which, IMO, is more a way to push people into holding coins (taking them out of supply) because you have no other use for them, and when people do that, it can temporarily hold the price up

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> Could the processing of transactions be separated from the wallet holding the coins somehow?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> we believe that with PBaaS, people will have a lot of use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but also yes. there are ways to do that, which effectively would provide a delegated staking function

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Patrick ManBearPig> I've seen some talk of signing or something or other

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i have a call and then will be focused on PBaaS development. i don't have a way of hardware wallet staking yet without delegation, but i will keep a background thread on it, and we can revisit after PBaaS

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> @Patrick ManBearPig, This reddit post has a basic interpretation of what PBaaS should generally encompass-
https://www.reddit.com/r/CryptoCurrency/comments/au3j49/comment/eh7zut5

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Here is the excerpt-

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> -PBaaS: or Public Blockchain as a Service is a revolutionary new take on the blockchain as a service model entirely unique to Verus that offers the tools and necessary means to build on and utilize blockchain technology for business or personal use. It is similar to using a web hosting service to build a website with, but rather than having to build one by yourself from scratch, the service provider supplies the basics and handles all the necessary tasks from general upkeep to infrastructure maintenance. Since Verus doesn't rely on a centralized authority to work, there isn't any one single point of failure in the network, so in the event of a hack, power failure, data breach or loss, Verus' system is immune while the other options aren't. Instead of relying on a centralized system, Verus elegantly does work for the public by utilizing the public to do work.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @jl777c IMO, with the delegation approach, it comes down to a decision of whether the loss of decentralization from delegation would be worth the convenience. Some projects do allow delegating your coins only for the purpose of staking, which would be pretty easy with CC's, as I guess you might be thinking with the leasing idea. I've also seen critiques of the centralization of these projects that are hard to argue with. I think there's a real security benefit to having all general users of Verus who have a PC staking as much as possible. I guess doing it with delegation might tend to centralize to the same or close to the same entities as pools and farms, which seems to reduce at least some of the security benefit you get from a hybrid algorithm.
